detailsOfAchievement: Established in 1919, the Sir Ratan Tata Trust (SRTT) is one of the oldest philanthropic institutions in India, and has played a pioneering role in changing traditional ideas of charity. It was established through a corpus of Rs. 8.1 million - a princely sum in those days - in accordance with the will of Sir Ratan (the younger son of Jamsetjee Tata). Over the past 80 years, the Trusts have built a systematic agenda across the country, tying in with organizations and individuals to design and implement solutions to problems in issues as varied as Urban Poverty, Livelihoods, Natural Resource Management, Arts, Crafts and Culture, water, agriculture, education, health and sanitation. Now, with the changing focus, there is greater involvement in areas like microfinance, market development, delivery systems and data management. Along with this, the Trusts are endeavouring to ensure the incorporation of the following facets in all future engagements; namely: (a) scalability of the interventions; (b) measurable impact; and (c) sustainability of the community served, post withdrawal of the Trustsâ€™ support. Currently, the Trustsâ€™ work is spread across 170 districts in 17 states of the country, touching the lives of over 800,000 households through interventions that include drinking water and sanitation, health and nutrition, agriculture, education, arts, crafts and culture and skill development. Programmes of the Trust have seen the disbursal of Rs. 1.48 billion (US $ 24.74 million) during the last financial year. These funds include collaboration with government and non-governmental programmes, and have a multi-fold impact on the ground.

detailsOfAchievement: SYYED AHMAD SARWAJANIK WACHANALAY,PUSAD (REGD.) started its academic and admimistrative oprations and registred on 18.08.1998 has been functioning as a legally constituted public organisation and is registered under the Societies Registration Act XXI of 1860 & 1950. The library is working according to a written Constitution drawn by its members for smooth and efficient working. The Library has along and excellent record of service in the field of imparting awareness on education, social welfare and upliftment of the weaker section general public and spcialy for women of the society.During last ten years is involved in various activities, has focused primarily on Education and Literacy, Empowerment of Women and Gender issues, promotion of Urdu,Hindi and Marathi Languages in muslim area Child litrature Development, Problem of Working and Street Children, Awareness on Basic education, Promotion of Education, Road Safety Awareness, Rural & urban Education Development, Environmental issues and other Social and Community Development Programmes. Our goal is to enable the disadvantaged section of the muslim community in society to recognize the importance of their role, initiatives and participate in the process of development and shape their future course accordingly. It is our dream- (1)To perpetuate the memory of Sir syyad Ahmad Khan and his age. (2)To conduct on Sir syyad Ahmad Khan in India (3)To arrange for the education of oriental languages for the study of Sir syyad Ahmad Khan and his age. (4)To collaborate with Libraries,Societies,Organizatiopn or Institution carrying on kindred activities. (5)To promote,develop,and progagate Urdu,Hindi,and Marathi languages.

title: Sound and Picture Archives for Research on Women SPARROW

isuues.name: Key Issues
isuues.value: Art & Culture,Education & Literacy,Human Rights,Information & Communication Technology,Minority Issues,Panchayati Raj,Science & Technology,Women's Development & Empowerment

detailsOfAchievement: SPARROW is an archive for women that collects oral history and visual material connected with the lives and experience of women as important material for future research on women. Our intention is to make such material more visible and accessible to people interested in the history of women. The scope of our work includes the whole of India and the South Asian continent, It is conceived as a national archives of women and collecting material from all over India on all issues that affect women like domestic violence, environment, political activism, feminism, human rights, minority rights, Dalit issues, literature, art and scholarship. Throughout its existence in the last twenty years SPARROW has functioned as an archiving body which in addition to collecting material on the history and lives of women, has also generated its own archival material through oral history recordings, digital video recordings, publications, exhibitions and workshops with students in schools and colleges as well as reaching out to media and communication groups and groups formed by women. One of our major achievements is that we have brought the history of women to the public sphere. We have brought out more than 33 publications, several reports and held 17 workshops two of which have been summer workshops for American students. We have conducted one Film Festival called Lives of Women and Words of Women, a Cultural Festival with films, paintings and handicrafts from the North East regions of India called One River, Many Streams, held a Camp for Writers and made 25 oral history digital documentaries ten of them under the title Global Feminisms in collaboration with the University of Michigan. Currently we are working on five volumes of the writings of women with 67 writers from 23 languages. Along with all this we have also been cataloging and digitizing our material. We now have a permanent building.
